p:
Fruit damage due to the native tephritid fruit fly species in East Africa was already high, causing serious problems to growers. This situation was exacerbated with the invasion of B. dorsalis, with damage frequently reaching 100% in the absence of effective pest management
3, 18, 19 . This highly invasive species has since displaced local fruit fly species from smallholder crops
3 . The relative economic impact is perhaps strongest felt by smallholder farming families that count on the small-scale sales of high-value crops to significantly contribute to the family economics. Pest management and control strategies should thus be amenable to both large-scale productions and small-scale farming, with emphasis on the latter. However, little is known about the potential of adoption and utilization of fruit fly control techniques in smallholder farming settings.
